item.title: Linux 3d?
item.dc:creator: @kloplop321 kloplop321
item.description:
@kloplop321 wrote:

It worked perfectly on 3 different test drives(4 gigs, got them all free from school as they are now obsolete) but thanks to get databack for NTFS i got most of my back ups back, it took 2 hours to form a VB .NET project I had on there as the program would save the raw data on the other hard drive as a $???.EXT(extension in CAPS) and some of the names of the files were lost, but anyway. Thanks for the advice, I don’t personally know you, but I wish I did.

Read full topic

item.title: Linux 3d?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

The Sabayon full installation from the DVD takes up an insane 11gb, kubuntu takes about 2.4, so you could clear off a little bit of space and install kubuntu, I run it just fine off of 10gb.

And it is easy to install to the same disk as windows, the key is to make sure you defragment your harddrive in windows first before you go to install, then just follow the easy instructions.

Read full topic

item.title: Linux 3d?
item.dc:creator: @kloplop321 kloplop321
item.description:
@kloplop321 wrote:

I did see it, I will check it out, If only Windows and Linux on my computer would work together and wouldn’t argue on partition rights.
could you make a tutorial on actually installing Linux, and Windows on the same computer, on the same hard drive? because last time… I kinda lost 120 gigs on back ups, and some of the back ups were the only ones that existed… and I only have 4 gig hard drives to spare… I’m planning to reinstall the windows that came with this computer as it is kinda corroding and it is ready to die soon, no viruses, but just starting to corrode.

Read full topic

item.title: Linux 3d?

item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

kloplop321:

still looks really awsome, can you install this while on the boot disk of ubuntu?

Sure if you have enough RAM, but you probably don’t.

Scroll up to my first post for the link to sabayon, which uses it by default.

item.title: Linux 3d?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

kmb:

I’m using Beryl on Ubuntu 6.10 atm. TBH it’s just some very useless eye candy. Oh and Frostwire doesn’t work with Beryl, I have to use Metacity instead.

I’ve come to find out it is a problem with Swing somehow, any applications that use Swing don’t repaint when you start them in beryl.

You have to:

  1. Start the java program, wait until it shows up, it will be blank
  2. switch the window manager to metacity/kde/xfce, the java program will look normal
  3. switch back to beryl, the java program remains normal and useable

I really hope the people working on beryl fix this soon.

Read full topic
